an4.67:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an4.67:4.2: Now, at that time a monk in Sāvatthī died of snakebite.
an4.67:4.3: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha,
an4.67:4.4: bowed, sat down to one side,
an4.67:4.6: “Sir, a monk in Sāvatthī has died of snakebite.”
an4.67:5.1: “Mendicants, that monk mustn’t have spread a mind of love to the four royal snake families.
an4.67:5.2: If he had, he wouldn’t have died of snakebite.
an4.67:6.2: The royal snake families of Virūpakkha, Erāpatha, Chabyāputta, and Kaṇhāgotamaka. …
an4.67:7.1: Mendicants, I urge you to spread a mind of love to the four royal snake families, for your own safety, security, and protection.”
an4.67:10.1: May the footless not harm me!
an4.67:10.2: May I not be harmed by the two-footed!
an4.67:10.3: May the four-footed not harm me!
an4.67:10.4: May I not be harmed by the many-footed!
an4.67:11.1: All sentient beings, all living things,
an4.67:11.3: may they see only good things,
an4.67:11.4: may bad not come to anyone.
an4.67:13.3: I’ve made this safeguard, I’ve made this protection:
an4.67:13.5: And so I revere the Blessed One,
an4.67:13.6: I revere the seven perfectly awakened Buddhas.”
